name: Binturong
description: The largest civet-like carnivore, with females larger than males. Distinctive features include long tufts of fur on the ear pinnae and bright brown to brick-red eyes. Its tail is prehensile. The subspecies A. b. whitei, currently kept, is smaller than the mainland subspecies, with black fur and more pronounced white edges on the ear pinnae.
spread_note: Southeast Asia, including some Indonesian islands; the subspecies A. b. whitei lives on Sumatra.
food_note: Mainly fruits, occasionally smaller animals, bird eggs, carrion
proportions: Body length 61–96 cm; tail length 61–96 cm; weight 20–25 kg
reproduction: Females are pregnant for 90–92 days, giving birth to 2–3 (rarely 4) young.
attractions: It resides in tree canopies, where it climbs skillfully, sleeps, and raises its young in branches. It also swims excellently. Active at dusk, occasionally during the day, it prefers sweet fruits and plays a significant role in seed dispersal for various trees. It typically lives solitarily; groups encountered in the wild are usually a female with grown offspring.
breeding: Since 1959, binturongs intermittently inhabited the Rare Animals Pavilion (now Africa Up Close) until 1994. After a break, new animals arrived at the Indonesian Jungle pavilion. The first was a female from Hanoi in 2005, followed by a pair in 2006 and another female in 2007. The male from that pair still lives; in 2013, he was transferred to another zoo due to the arrival of a new subspecies. The first successful breeding occurred in 2009 with twins, followed by nine more offspring. In early 2014, a pair of Palawan binturongs (A. b. whitei) settled in the pavilion.
